profileText: A Delegate from New York; born in New York City February 6, 1733; completed preparatory studies; studied law; was admitted to the bar August 3, 1754; clerk of the chancery court in 1762; attorney general of New York in 1767; boundary commissioner in 1768 and 1784; State Indian commissioner in 1774; delegate to the provincial convention in 1775; member of the Revolutionary Committee of One Hundred in 1775; Member of the Continental Congress 1774-1783; member of the Provincial Congress in 1776 and 1777; served in the State senate 1782-1785 and 1788-1790; chosen a member of the Annapolis Commercial Convention in 1786, but did not attend; first mayor of New York City 1784-1789; delegate to the State convention which ratified the Federal Constitution in 1788; United States district judge for the district of New York 1789-1794; believed to have died in either New York City or in Duanesburg, Schenectady County, N.Y., February 1, 1797; interment under Christ Church in Duanesburg.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Alexander, Edward P. "A Revolutionary Conservative: James Duane of New York," Ph. D. diss., Columbia University, 1938.
___. Revolutionary Conservative: James Duane of New York. New York: AMS Press, 1978.
Duane, James. The Duane Letters [1761-1789]. N.p., n.d.

___. State of the Evidence and Argument in Support of the Territorial Rights and Jurisdiction of New York Against the Government of New Hampshire and the Claimants Under It, and Against the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. New York: n.p., 1871.
Jones, Samuel W. Memoir of the Hon. James Duane, Judge of the District Court of the U. States for New York. 1849. Reprint, [Schenectady]: Keyser, printer, 1852.

researchRecord.name: In the Peter Force Collection, 1752-1786, 200 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers are also available on microfilm. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Cushing Family Papers, 1773-1857, 1 box.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include James Duane.

researchRecord.name: In the Alexander Hamilton Papers, 1780, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Alexander Hamilton to Judge James Duane written on October 18, 1780. Alexander Hamilton expresses his pleasure that General Gates is to be removed and succeeded by General Greene in the South.

researchRecord.name: In the John Jay Papers, 1785, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Jay to Samuel Johnson written on October 12, 1785. The letter is also signed by other individuals, including James Duane. The signers express that they would not be ready to meet the federal court appointed to decide an unspecified controversy.

researchRecord.name: In the Richard Montgomery Papers, 1775, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Richard Montgomery to James Duane written on July 21, 1775. Richard Montgomery accepts his commission from Congress.

researchRecord.name: n.d., 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Duane to Gerard Banker.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1772, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Duane to an unidentified recipient written on January 14, 1772.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1779, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Duane to Pierce Van Cortland, President of the Senate, and Evert Bancker, Speaker of the Assembly, written on August 29, 1779.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1778, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Duane to George Clinton written on March 13, 1778. James Duane writes concerning the treaty with the Six Nations of the Iroquois at John's Town, the failure of plans for a second invasion of Canada under Lafayette, and of James Duane's refusal to accept an appointment as a commissioner of Indian affairs.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1785, 2 volumes.
researchRecord.description: A formal statement of evidence and argument in favor of New York State's boundary rights written by James Duane as a member of the state appointed by the committee charged with the task of garnering evidence to substantiate the State's boundary claims relevant to the properties known as the New Hampshire Grants, including lands south of the Connecticut River, in what is today the state of Vermont.

researchRecord.name: In the Duane and Featherstonhaugh Family Papers, ca. 1666-1900, 7.5 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The major portion of the collection are the papers of James Duane. James Duane's notebooks, 1765-1789, contain daily notes on his activities, land transactions, and improvements at Duanesburgh, his Albany law practice, his service as a delegate to Congress, including his expenses, Livingston Manor, a trip with Lafayette to Albany, traveling with Luzerne from Morristown to Philadelphia, depreciation of money, costs of lands withheld by the Vermonters, and public roads out of Duanesburgh. His legal papers include briefs, notes, declarations, narratives, and arguments.

researchRecord.name: In the Walter Rutherfurd Papers, 1777-1794, 18 items.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include James Duane.

researchRecord.name: In the William Samuel Johnson Papers, 1753-1802, 1 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include James Duane.

researchRecord.name: In the Van Schaack Family Papers, 1686-1887, 3 reels.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include James Duane.

researchRecord.name: 1781, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Duane to M. Brashier written on August 24, 1781. James Duane requests two certificates: one certificate states the facts regarding a debate in convention on the attempt to seize Governor Tryon; the second certificate states when James Duane's orders to prevent Governor Tryon's seizure were received.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1790, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Duane to his son-in-law, Major William North, discussing the lease of some land to a young Scotsman, Mr. Edgar.

researchRecord.name: In the Duanesburg Patent Land Papers, 1734-1835, 76 items.
researchRecord.description: This is a collection of papers relating to the lands in the Duanesburg Patent, recording several transfers of title by various speculators leading to the acquisition by Anthony and James Duane of some 100,000 acres. An unpublished guide is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the William North Papers, 1763-1820, 66 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondence with James Duane concern lands in the Duanesburgh Patent and in the Steuben and Montgomery counties. An unpublished partial calendar is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Melancton Smith Papers, 1786-1792, 1 box.
researchRecord.description: Subjects covered in the papers include James Duane. An unpublished inventory is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the John Williams Papers, 1767-1841, 1500 items.
researchRecord.description: Subjects covered in the papers include James Duane. An unpublished inventory is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Folly Farm Papers of the Smith, Lewis and Cochran Families, 1774-1891, 842 items.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include James Duane. A guide to the papers is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the New York Common Council Records, 1780, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A voucher containing a payment request to General Malcom for the sum of sixteen pounds of gun powder to be used by the militia for the arrival of President Washington to New York. The voucher is signed by Mayor James Duane on April 22, 1789.

parentRecordLocation.name: New York City Department of Records and Information Services

researchRecord.name: In the Philip John Schuyler Papers, 1684-1851, 21 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include James Duane. A finding aid is available in the repository.
